speaker: Frasier
text: This is Dr. Frasier Crane, wishing you all good mental health.

speaker: Roz
text: Happy anniversary!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz!  Oh, this is so much fun, Roz!  I got you one too!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, thank you!  O.K., you first.  I mean, it's nothing really, it's not expensive or anything, you probably won't even like it, I'm not good with gifts--

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, don't oversell it, Roz. [_unwraps it_] It's a tape. [_reads_] "The Dr. Frasier Crane Show: Show #1, May 21st, 1993."

speaker: Roz
text: It's our first broadcast.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz!  I can't wait to listen to it!  Did you ever think I'd stay on the air this long?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, hell no. [_reads her card_] "To Roz, who believed in me from the start."

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, it's from Hallmark's "Irony" section.

speaker: Roz
text: [_opens hers_] Oh, Frasier, they're beautiful!  Earrings! Thank you, thank you!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_hugs her_] You deserve them.  Working side by side for three years, one can't help but become close friends.  And they're blue!  To match your... lips when they're cold!  _She rolls her eyes at him as he goes out the door.  FADE OUT  Scene Two -- Frasier's Apartment It's later that afternoon.  Outside, the rain is pouring.  Daphne is wandering around the apartment, dusting things and talking on the cordless phone._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, Mum, it's not that I don't want to come home.  I'd love a visit!  It's just that I can't!  He won't let me.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, you have no idea what Dr. Crane is like.  Why, he's an absolute beast -- unpleasant to be around, a real tyrant!

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh! [_whispering_] It's just my mum.  I'm trying to get out of a visit home.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_whispering_] Oh, I understand.  All right.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_into phone_] No, I'm not exaggerating!  He treats me like a bloody slave!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_shouting_] Daphne!  Where's my dressing gown?!

speaker: Daphne
text: Not to mention how cheap he is!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_as she holds the phone towards him_] That better not be a long-distance call!

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, yeah.  He does sound a lot like Aunt Lillian.  _She holds the phone towards him.  He mouths, "I can't do Aunt Lillian."_

speaker: Daphne
text: I got to run, Mum.  Love you, bye. [_hangs up_] I'm sorry, you must think I'm a terrible daughter.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, not at all.  I think you're a terrible liar, Daphne, but a perfectly run-of-the-mill daughter.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's just that I only get one vacation a year, and I want to go somewhere fun, like Acapulco.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that makes sense.  _Daphne takes the flowers to the kitchen to put them in some water. Frasier puts his tape into the stereo and pours himself a glass of sherry._

speaker: Daphne
text: And going home is just so flipping boring.  It's always the same.  There's a wonderful reunion at the airport, and we share all our news on the way home in the car.  And by the time I've dropped off my suitcase, we've exhausted all conversation, and that's when I realize I've got a whole week left with nothing to look forward to but Dad telling the story of how he once shared a cigar with Winston Churchill during the blackouts -- he thinks!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it sounds like an easy decision, Daphne -- [_raises his glass_] _Hasta luego._

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, Dr. Crane, why is it so easy to love our families, yet so hard to like them?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Daphne, that is one of those questions that make life so rich... and psychiatrists richer.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, well, maybe I'll just go call a travel agent, see which guilt trip is more expensive. _Daphne goes to her room.  Frasier starts the tape and settles in the armchair by the windows.  Eddie jumps into his lap and stares at him._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_v.o.; sounding ridiculous_] Good afternoon, Seattle.  My name is Dr. Frasier Crane.  If you can feel, I can heal.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fasten your seat belt, Eddie.  It's going to be a bumpy ride. **MAY 21, 1993 1:57 PM**  _Scene Three -- KACL Frasier opens the door to his radio booth.  He surveys it for a moment like a painter sizing up a blank canvass, and satisfies himself that it is all right.  He places his briefcase on the console, just right.  He fumbles with the spare microphone and quickly puts it down.  Then he pulls up his chair to the main microphone, and positions it just right for his sitting position.  Finally satisfied, he takes a set of practice cards out of his jacket pocket._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello.  You're on the air with Dr. Frasier Crane. [_reading_] "Put your head in my hands."  _He throws the card away.  He starts again, but stops and clears his throat a few times.  Not satisfied, he does a few "me-me-me-me's" and little Indian war whoops to warm his voice up.  Finally, he gets up and paces the booth, doing an elocution exercise._

speaker: Frasier
text: "Little owlet in the glen, I am ashamed of you, You are ungrammatical in speaking as you do, You should say, 'to whom, to whom,' not 'to who, to who.' Your little friend, Miss Katydid, may be green, 'tis true, But you never heard her say--" [_turns around and sees Roz staring at him_] Who the hell are you?

speaker: Roz
text: I'm Roz Doyle, your new producer.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?  Producer?

speaker: Roz
text: [_shaking his hand_] Dr. Crane, I presume?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes, but, uh, where's Dave?

speaker: Roz
text: Uh, he got another assignment.  _Roz starts arranging things around the booth to get ready for the show.  Frasier follows her around._

speaker: Frasier
text: But I was comfortable with Dave.

speaker: Roz
text: Look, Dr. Crane, I know you've been thrown a curve, but everything's gonna be fine.

speaker: Frasier
text: But I did a mock show with Dave.  I did mock-call-in's, mock commercials, mock news bulletins!

speaker: Roz
text: Look, I got a bulletin for you: Dave's out, I'm in, and stop saying "mock."

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, look, Miss Doyle, I'm sure you're quite capable, but Dave has fifteen years of experience.  I'd really prefer that he do it.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, that would make two of us then, wouldn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: I really think I should call management and ask for Dave, it's not really fair to Dave or to me.

speaker: Roz
text: Dr. Crane, Dave dumped you.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_whiny_] Why?  We were here until 2 A.M. this morning, as I explained to Dave in meticulous detail my philosophy of optimal mental health!

speaker: Roz
text: It's a mystery, all right.  O.K., look, I'm going to screen a few calls, and--

speaker: Frasier
text: No!  No, no, as I explained to Dave before, there will be no call-screening.  You see, I want my show to be fresh and spontaneous, and call screening squelches all of that.

speaker: Roz
text: And the mystery of Dave's departure deepens.  OK, you're on in five seconds, I'll give you a cue.  _Frasier sits in his chair and puts on his headphones.  Roz goes into her booth, puts on the headphones, and points to him.  Frasier hesitates for a second, then reads from his next note card._

speaker: Frasier
text: Good afternoon, Seattle.  My name is Dr. Frasier Crane. [_reads_] "If you can feel, I can heal." _Roz rolls her eyes.  Frasier throws the card away.  Silence for a few seconds.  Alarmed, Roz signals that there's dead air._

speaker: Frasier
text: Let's see who's on line one! [_pushes button_] Hello, this is Dr. Frasier Crane.  [_reading_] "You're on the couch."

speaker: Angela
text: [_v.o._] No, I'm not.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I meant on the metaphorical couch.

speaker: Angela
text: I'm in a beanbag chair, O.K.? _Frasier throws the card away, then picks up the microphone and starts to lean back in his chair._

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, moving on then, um, how can I help you?

speaker: Angela
text: It's about my husband... Look, I-I just can't do this, it's really too embarrassing for me.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, please, please, dear friend, you must - I'm really here to help you.  Please, go ahead. _Unfortunately, he leans too far and topples over backward in his chair. Scrambling back to his feet, he grabs the wire to his headphones and pulls it hand-over-hand to get back his headphones and put them on._

speaker: Angela
text: ...I've tried, and I've tried, and I just don't know what to do about this!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, often in these cases, it helps if you restate your problem.  But this time, try boiling it down to one succinct sentence.  Now, how would you do that?

speaker: Angela
text: My husband is dead!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, perhaps we should go back to the wordy version. [_Angela hangs up_] Uh, we'll be right back after these important messages.  _He quickly goes to commercial and walks into Roz's booth.  Roz is talking on the phone._

speaker: Roz
text: Of course I could do a gardening show.  If I can grow plants in my dorm room closet, I must know a thing or two about horticulture--

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you trying to get transferred?

speaker: Roz
text: Bye! [_hangs up_] Look, Dr. Crane, I got to be honest with you here.  It's just that I-I think psychiatry is, just, uh, sort of - kind of... bull! [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well, this is a match made in heaven then, isn't it?!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, don't be offended.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Don't be offended."  Why should I be offended?  In the last week, I've uprooted myself from my home of fifteen years, moved all the way across the country away from everything I care about, and plunged myself into a frightening new career!  The first few nerve-wracking moments, I walk in here and find my producer lobbying to get herself transferred to another show!  Abe Lincoln had a brighter future when he picked up his tickets at the box office! _Frasier storms out of the booth.  Roz calmly sits back down. Frasier comes running back in and throws himself into his chair. Roz cues him, and the show goes on.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_  **MAY 21, 1993 5:13 PM**  _Scene Four -- Cafe Nervosa Frasier and Roz are sitting at a corner table.  Roz reads from a notebook. _

speaker: Roz
text: O.K., you got to make the caller get to the point, and then for God's sake, so should you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Duly noted.

speaker: Roz
text: O.K.  Number twenty-four... [_looks at him_] You know what, you're starting to glaze.  We can go through the rest of this tomorrow.  See you, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bye, Roz.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, excuse me.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, excuse you.  _Roz leaves.  Niles turns and looks back at this rude and (as-yet) unknown woman, then stands in line._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Frasier! [_comes over to the table_] What a serendipitous event.  How did you discover my favorite coffee bar?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, the radio station's right across the street.  I did my first show today.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, you did, didn't you?  Well... good to see you, have a nice day!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, aren't you going to join me?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, well, I would, but I have a routine.  I come in every day, order coffee and spend some quality time... with myself, you understand.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I've seen you once in the last two years.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, that is your point.  Well... very well, in the spirit of blood being thicker than water, why don't we?  _They sit at Frasier's table.  Or rather, Frasier does.  Niles first takes out his handkerchief and wipes his chair down._

speaker: Frasier
text: I remember your fourth birthday party.  Grandmother took us to the park to ride the carousel, and made all those little children wait while you wiped off your painted pony.

speaker: Niles
text: I was wearing Bermuda shorts and that saddle was slick with toddler sweat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, uh... oh, uh, thanks again for dinner the other night with Maris.  You two seem very happy.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh yes, it's love.  Like the Arctic Puffin, we've mated for life.  Honestly, I can't imagine even looking at another woman. _Realizing there are no napkins at their table, Niles turns to another table to get some.  As he does, the woman at the next table -- Daphne -- turns to Frasier._

speaker: Daphne
text: Excuse me, sir, have you finished with that sugar?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes.  _Daphne takes the sugar and turns back to her table as Niles turns back to Frasier.  Niles stops and sniffs the air for a second, then shakes his head and sits back down.  A waiter comes up._  Waiter: You ready to order?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, yes.  Double decaf non-fat latte, mmm... medium foam, dusted with just the faintest whisper of cinnamon.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll have a black coffee.

speaker: Niles
text: You'll have to forgive my brother.  He just came in on the noon stage.

speaker: Frasier
text: I hope I never see the day when I am so frightfully pretentious that a good-old cup of American coffee isn't good enough for me.

speaker: Niles
text: So, how'd your visit with Dad go?

speaker: Frasier
text: I haven't been to see him yet.

speaker: Niles
text: Really?  You've been in town a whole week.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I've been very busy, what with settling into the new apartment, unpacking...

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, you're obviously making excuses.  I'm going over tonight for my weekly visit, why don't you come along?

speaker: Frasier
text: Geez, I know I should, Niles.  But I'm really in such a vulnerable state right now.  The last thing I need is Seattle's reigning sourpuss taking potshots at me.

speaker: Niles
text: Is that what you're worried about?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you have been out of touch.  Our father's a changed man. Ever since he was shot, he's softened, with a whole new zest for life!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I visited him in the hospital.  He made his roommate cry, and the man was in a coma.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad was still in shock.  The change came after.  As a psychiatrist surely you've seen this?  A patient has a brush with death and rediscovers his love of life.  Ah, [_chuckles_] the laughs we've had when I'm over there. I sometimes wonder if that bullet didn't crease his funny bone.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh... thank you. [_the waiter leaves_] Can you believe the incompetence of that man?  I very clearly asked for a whisper of cinnamon, he's given me a full-throated shout!  There are countries in this world where they would lop off his sprinkling hand! _Niles takes a spoon and starts scooping cinnamon off the top of his coffee._

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, I'd forgotten what a weird little person you are. _FADE TO:  Scene Five -- Martin's Apartment Niles leads Frasier down the hall to Martin's door._

speaker: Niles
text: Dad is going to be positively giddy when he sees that he's got the both of us tonight. [_knocks "shave and a haircut"_] _Inside his apartment, Martin is sitting in his beloved Barcalounger -- only here he has a matching couch, a dartboard on the wall -- i.e., a fairly blue-collar dwelling.  He's watching a baseball game on TV. _

speaker: Martin
text: Who is it?

speaker: Niles
text: Niles, and a special guest!

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, jeez... all right, hold your horses.

speaker: Niles
text: [_chuckling_] How does he come up with those? [_Martin opens the door_] Look, Dad, it's Frasier!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I can see that.  That punk didn't shoot out my eyeball.

speaker: Niles
text: [_chuckling_] Stop it! [_to Frasier_] He sees the humor in everything.

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, come on in.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks, Dad.  [_they come in_] So, big game?

speaker: Martin
text: Nah, they're losing again.  Pitcher's a bum.

speaker: Niles
text: He's a bum, he's an absolute hobo! [_chuckling_] Isn't that right, Skipper?

speaker: Martin
text: Niles, are you drunk?

speaker: Niles
text: [_chuckling_] Don't be ridiculous!  Seeing the three of us back together again in the same room -- who needs alcohol for that?

speaker: Martin
text: I do.

speaker: Frasier
text: I do.

speaker: Martin
text: I'll get you a beer.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thanks, Dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: You filthy liar!  You said he'd changed!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, it got you here, didn't it?  I've been dealing with him all by myself ever since Mom died.  Now it's your turn, so welcome home, prodigal son!

speaker: Martin
text: [_o.s._] You guys want some pork rinds?

speaker: Niles
text: And that's as close as you're going to get to a fatted calf.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, thanks, Dad.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, will you stop staring at me?

speaker: Martin
text: Here you go.

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, well, I understand completely, Frasier.  Dad, Frasier was just saying that he'd like to spend some quality time with you alone, so I'm just going to slip out.

speaker: Martin
text: All right, suit yourself.

speaker: Niles
text: All right... oh, you haven't met Eddie. [_picks up Eddie and turns him around to face Frasier_] Eddie?  Frasier is the firstborn.  [_Eddie stares at Frasier_] The torch has been passed.  _Niles leaves.  Martin sits down in his chair.  The following conversation is filled with uncomfortable silences._

speaker: Frasier
text: So...

speaker: Martin
text: How was your flight?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, actually, I drove.

speaker: Martin
text: You take the I-Ninety?

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, Eighty.

speaker: Martin
text: Should have taken Ninety, it would have got you here faster.

speaker: Frasier
text: Darn.  So, Dad, did you listen to my show today?

speaker: Martin
text: No, I missed it.  Sorry.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's all right.

speaker: Martin
text: How'd it go?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, uh, kind of rocky.  Spent a good part of the day puzzling over the proper signature line to use to introduce myself.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I'm sure you'll come up with something.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, I'm looking for something that's familiar but not a cliche, you know, something that's memorable but not too gimmicky... [_Martin turns on the television_] You know, it doesn't really matter if it's got something to--Dad, please, I'm trying to have a conversation, it's hard with the TV on.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I just want to get the score, O.K.?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm trying to describe to you my dilemna with that phrase--

speaker: Martin
text: [_turns off TV_] All right, fine, I'm listening.  Are you happy?  I'm listening.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's it!  "I'm listening!"  That's fabulous!  Have you got a pencil somewhere?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, there's one in the kitchen on the table.

speaker: Frasier
text: "I'm listening."  Dad - oh, I love that!  _Frasier heads into the kitchen.  Martin gets up and gets his jacket from the closet._

speaker: Martin
text: Uh, look, I hate to cut this short, but I told some guys I'd meet 'em down at Duke's.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're leaving?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  Whenever you're ready, I'll walk you out.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I haven't seen you in two years, I stopped by and you're leaving in ten minutes?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, why don't we stop kidding ourselves?  You don't really want to be here, and we don't really have anything to talk about.

speaker: Frasier
text: At least I'm making the effort.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah -- it's an effort to talk to me, huh?  Well, I guess that's why you only bother coming home once a year at Christmas.  Oh no, wait!  Sorry, I take that back.  Last year you went to Arugalah, wherever the hell that is.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you know you're painting an awfully bleak picture here. Ever since I moved to Boston, I've come home at least three or four times a year.  It's just lately things got a little hectic, and I haven't been able to come home as often.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah... I noticed how busy you got after your mother died.

speaker: Martin
text: But, what the hell, I didn't go visit you in Boston either, did I?  So, uh, why don't we just drop this?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.  The point is that we're here now, together.  I don't want this night to end before we've at least tried to have one real conversation.  Will you at least try, Dad?  Will you just sit down with me for a while and let's try, please?  _Martin sits back in his Armchair.  Frasier sits on the couch. There's silence for a few moments._

speaker: Frasier
text: So, uh, you know, I'd forgotten how much it really does rain here.

speaker: Martin
text: You get used to it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Makes things green.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah... where would the old earth be without rain?  _Silence again.  Frasier picks up the remote and turns the TV back on. Eddie continues to stare at him.  FADE TO:  Scene Six -- Frasier's Apartment Back to the Present.  It's now evening.  Frasier is asleep in his chair, and Eddie is still sitting in his lap.  Frasier wakes up and sees Eddie staring at him._

speaker: Frasier
text: My darling, I would have thought that old fascination would wear off by now. _He gives Eddie a great big kiss on the head.  Eddie runs off. Niles and Martin come in the door._

speaker: Niles
text: Well, hello, there!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hey, guys.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, Dad tells me you've been on the air three years today, so we'd like to take you out for a celebratory dinner.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thank you.  Dad, how did you know?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I heard that woman who called in.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_surprised_] You listened to my show?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I sort of... I feel asleep during the Mariners' game... but when I woke up, you were on.

speaker: Frasier
text: And you didn't turn me off.

speaker: Martin
text: I did not!  I listened to you for ten minutes before I finally dozed off again. [_laughs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Faint praise, and yet it thunders in my ears!

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Daphne, we're going out to dinner.  You want to join us?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, thanks, but no.  I promised myself that tonight I'd decide what I'm doing on my vacation -- either home to the family or to sunny Acapulco.  I may just squeeze into my bikini and let my hips make the decision.

speaker: Niles
text: Of course, it would be more memorable if we celebrated at home, just for a--

speaker: Frasier
text: Let's go, let's go!

speaker: Daphne
text: Have a lovely time!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, fellas, hold the elevator for me.

speaker: Niles
text: All right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne?

speaker: Frasier
text: I was just thinking about our discussion earlier this afternoon, and I've decided to give you an extra week off.  That way you can go to Manchester, _and_ Acapulco.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, that's so sweet!  You really must think I should go home.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I've just realized that being part of a family is really worth the effort.  And very often the effort... means you'll need a week in Acapulco, so...

speaker: Daphne
text: [_kisses him on the cheek and hugs him_] Thank you, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're welcome.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_sighs_] I guess if I try a little harder, it won't be so bad.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's a good way of thinking.  You know, things can get better.

speaker: Martin
text: [_o.s._] Hey, let's go!  I got acid burning a hole in my stomach!
